metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management
clauses.rationale: PM-07 enterprise architecture; PM-08 critical infrastructure; PM-11 mission/business process definition. Mission context well addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes organizational context beyond pure security mission alignment.

clauses.title: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
clauses.rationale: PM-08 critical infrastructure planning includes stakeholders; PM-11 mission process definition; PM-15 security contacts.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires systematic stakeholder identification and expectation analysis. SP 800-53 partially addresses through program-level controls.

clauses.title: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity are understood and managed
clauses.rationale: PM-01 program plan addresses legal context; PL-04 rules of behavior; SA-04 contractual requirements.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 lacks a dedicated legal/regulatory requirements identification control. Federal compliance assumed in FISMA context.

clauses.title: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on are understood and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-08 critical infrastructure; PM-11 mission processes; CP-02 contingency planning includes critical service identification.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires explicit identification of stakeholder-dependent services. SP 800-53 addresses through mission/business process controls but less explicitly.

clauses.title: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-08/PM-11 mission/business dependencies; SA-09 external services; CP-02 contingency planning.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes understanding dependencies from supply chain and partner services. SP 800-53 partially covers through contingency and supply chain controls.

clauses.title: Risk management objectives are established and expressed as statements that articulate the basis for cybersecurity risk management decisions
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy; PM-28 risk framing; RA-01 risk assessment policy.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes explicit risk management objectives. SP 800-53 covers through risk strategy and framing.

clauses.title: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy includes risk tolerance; PM-28 risk framing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires explicit risk appetite statements. SP 800-53 addresses risk tolerance within strategy.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy; PM-28 risk framing at enterprise level; PM-01 program integration.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes ERM integration. SP 800-53 supports but the integration with non-security enterprise risk is less explicit.

clauses.title: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk strategy; RA-03 risk response identification; RA-07 risk response (new in Rev 5) directly addresses risk response options including accept, mitigate, share, or avoid; CA-05 remediation planning.
clauses.gaps: Minor: RA-07 significantly closes the gap by mandating risk response in accordance with risk tolerance.

clauses.title: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties
clauses.rationale: PM-15 security contacts; PM-16 threat awareness; IR-06/IR-07 incident communication; SR-01 supply chain risk.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes organizational risk communication pathways. SP 800-53 covers specific communication channels but systematic risk communication planning less explicit.

clauses.title: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated
clauses.rationale: RA-01 risk assessment policy; RA-02 categorization; RA-03 risk assessment methodology; PM-09 risk strategy.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires standardized risk calculation methodology. SP 800-53 RA-03 covers comprehensive risk assessment.

clauses.title: Strategic opportunities (positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy may include opportunity considerations.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 explicitly addresses positive risks/opportunities. SP 800-53 is threat/vulnerability focused and does not address strategic opportunities.

clauses.title: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving
clauses.rationale: PM-01 program plan; PM-02 senior security role; PM-13 workforce; AT-02 awareness.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes leadership accountability and culture. SP 800-53 addresses roles and awareness but organizational culture is less explicit.

clauses.title: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced
clauses.rationale: PM-02 role assignment; PS-01/PS-02 personnel roles; PS-09 position descriptions (new in Rev 5) explicitly incorporates security roles into position descriptions; PL-01 planning roles; PM-13 workforce.
clauses.gaps: Minimal: PS-09 strengthens the mapping by requiring security roles in position descriptions.

clauses.title: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles and responsibilities, and policies
clauses.rationale: PM-03 information security resources; PM-13 workforce resources; SA-02 allocation of resources.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 ties resource allocation to risk strategy. PM-03 addresses resources but risk-proportional allocation less explicit.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices
clauses.rationale: PS family comprehensive for personnel security; PS-09 position descriptions (new in Rev 5); AT family for training; PM-13 workforce development.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 PS/AT families well aligned with HR security practices.

clauses.title: A policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced
clauses.rationale: PL-01 planning policy and procedures; PM-01 information security program plan; PM-09 risk management strategy; PL-02 system security plans. Every control family has an -01 policy control.
clauses.gaps: Minimal: SP 800-53 requires policy for each family and a comprehensive program plan. Well aligned with CSF policy requirements.

clauses.title: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission
clauses.rationale: PL-01 includes periodic review; PM-01 program plan updates; PM-04 plan of action and milestones tracks needed changes; CA-07 continuous monitoring informs policy updates.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes policy review driven by threat landscape changes. SP 800-53 family -01 controls require periodic review but threat-driven updates are less explicit.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy review; PM-06 measures of performance; CA-07 continuous monitoring; PM-31 continuous monitoring strategy.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes strategic-level outcome review. SP 800-53 covers through monitoring and performance measures but explicit strategic adjustment is less formalized.

clauses.title: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk strategy; PM-28 risk framing; CA-02 security assessments inform strategy; RA-03 risk assessment.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires systematic strategy review for coverage. SP 800-53 addresses through risk assessment and strategy controls but explicit coverage reviews are less mandated.

clauses.title: Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed
clauses.rationale: PM-06 measures of performance; CA-07 continuous monitoring; PM-14 testing, training, and monitoring; CA-02 assessment results.
clauses.gaps: Minor: SP 800-53 provides strong assessment and monitoring capabilities for performance evaluation.

clauses.title: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
clauses.rationale: SR-01 supply chain risk management policy; SR-02 supply chain controls; SR-03 supply chain risk assessment; PM-30 supply chain risk management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 Rev 5 SR family is well aligned with CSF supply chain governance.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established and communicated
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition requirements; SA-09 external services; SR-01/SR-03 supply chain roles and assessments.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses customer and partner roles. SP 800-53 focuses on supplier roles.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes
clauses.rationale: SR-01/SR-02 supply chain integration; PM-09 risk strategy integration; PM-30 supply chain risk management plan.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes integration with broader enterprise risk. SP 800-53 addresses supply chain risk management but enterprise-wide integration is less explicit.

clauses.title: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality
clauses.rationale: SR-02 supply chain risk management plan covers supplier identification; SR-03 supply chain risk assessment includes criticality; SR-06 supplier assessments; SA-04 acquisition with security requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: SP 800-53 covers supplier criticality assessment through SR-03 risk assessment and SR-06 reviews.

clauses.title: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition processes include security requirements in contracts; SR-01 supply chain policy; SR-02 supply chain plan; SR-03 controls and processes.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SA-04 directly addresses contract requirements.

clauses.title: Planning and due diligence are conducted to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships
clauses.rationale: SR-03 supply chain controls; SR-05 acquisition strategies, tools, and methods; SR-06 supplier assessments and reviews; SA-04 acquisition processes.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes pre-engagement due diligence. SP 800-53 covers through acquisition and assessment controls.

clauses.title: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship
clauses.rationale: SR-02 supply chain plan; SR-03 ongoing supply chain assessment; SR-06 supplier reviews; RA-03 risk assessment; RA-07 risk response (new in Rev 5) ensures risk findings are responded to.
clauses.gaps: Minor: RA-07 strengthens coverage by ensuring systematic risk response. Ongoing monitoring through supplier relationship lifecycle is well covered.

clauses.title: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling coordination; IR-08 incident response plan; SR-08 notification agreements; CP-02 contingency plan.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes supplier inclusion in incident response. SR-08 notification agreements address communication but active supplier participation in exercises is less explicit.

clauses.title: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle
clauses.rationale: SR-01/SR-02/SR-03 supply chain risk management lifecycle; SR-06 ongoing assessments; PM-30 program integration; SA-03 system development lifecycle.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes lifecycle monitoring of supply chain practices. SP 800-53 covers through supply chain and lifecycle controls.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement
clauses.rationale: SR-12 component disposal; SA-04 acquisition/decommission requirements; SR-01 supply chain policy may cover termination; MP-06 media sanitization.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses post-relationship supply chain activities. SP 800-53 covers disposal but relationship termination planning is less formalized.

clauses.title: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained
clauses.rationale: CM-08 directly covers hardware component inventory with automated discovery; PM-05 system inventory.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained
clauses.rationale: CM-08 component inventory (includes software); PM-05 system inventory; CM-10 software usage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained
clauses.rationale: AC-04 information flow enforcement; PL-08 security architecture; CA-03 information exchange; SC-07 boundary definition; CM-12 information location (new in Rev 5) documents where information resides and how it flows.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CM-12 strengthens coverage by requiring documentation of information location and processing across system components.

clauses.title: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained
clauses.rationale: SA-09 external services identification; SR-06 supplier assessments; PM-05 system inventory.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires specific supplier service inventory. SP 800-53 covers through external service controls but dedicated inventory less explicit.

clauses.title: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact to the mission
clauses.rationale: RA-02 security categorization; PM-11 mission process definition; CP-02 contingency priority; PM-07 architecture priorities.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 combines multiple prioritization criteria. SP 800-53 covers through categorization and mission analysis.

clauses.title: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained
clauses.rationale: RA-02 data categorization; CM-08 component inventory; CM-12 information location (new in Rev 5) identifies and documents data locations; CM-13 data action mapping (new in Rev 5) maps data processing actions; SI-12 information management.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CM-12 and CM-13 significantly improve coverage by addressing data location tracking and data action mapping. Explicit metadata inventory management remains less formalized.

clauses.title: Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles
clauses.rationale: SA-03 SDLC; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-08 inventory lifecycle; SI-12 data lifecycle; MP-06 media sanitization.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires holistic lifecycle management. SP 800-53 covers through various lifecycle controls.

clauses.title: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-05 vulnerability identification and scanning; SI-02 flaw identification; SI-05 vulnerability advisories.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
clauses.rationale: PM-16 threat awareness program; SI-05 security alerts; PM-15 security contacts.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-03 risk assessment includes threat identification; PM-16 threat awareness; RA-10 threat hunting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-03 directly covers impact and likelihood assessment.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization
clauses.rationale: RA-03 comprehensive risk assessment; RA-07 risk response (new in Rev 5) mandates responding to assessment findings in accordance with risk tolerance; PM-09 risk strategy; CA-05 risk response prioritization.
clauses.gaps: Minimal: RA-07 strengthens coverage by formalizing risk response based on assessment findings.

clauses.title: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated
clauses.rationale: RA-07 risk response (new in Rev 5) is the primary control for risk response actions including accept, mitigate, share, and avoid; RA-03 risk response; PM-09 strategy; CA-05 POA&M tracking; PM-04 plan of action tracking.
clauses.gaps: Minimal: RA-07 directly addresses risk response selection and tracking, significantly improving coverage.

clauses.title: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, and recorded
clauses.rationale: CM-03 change control; CM-04 impact analysis; CA-06 authorization; RA-07 risk response (new in Rev 5) addresses exception handling through risk acceptance; PM-09 risk management.
clauses.gaps: Minor: RA-07 strengthens exception management through risk tolerance-based response. CSF 2.0 exception management well covered.

clauses.title: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established
clauses.rationale: RA-05 vulnerability management; SI-02 remediation; SI-05 advisories; PM-15 information sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses vulnerability disclosure processes (VDP). SP 800-53 covers vulnerability management but formal VDP less explicit.

clauses.title: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use
clauses.rationale: SR-04 provenance; SR-05 authenticity; SR-09 tamper resistance; SR-10 inspection; SR-11 component authenticity; SA-04 acquisition requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: SP 800-53 SR family covers hardware/software integrity comprehensively.

clauses.title: Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition
clauses.rationale: SR-03 supply chain assessment; SR-05 supply chain controls; SR-06 supplier assessments; SA-04 acquisition requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes pre-acquisition supplier assessment. SP 800-53 covers through supply chain and acquisition controls.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from evaluations
clauses.rationale: CA-02 assessment findings; CA-07 continuous monitoring improvements; PM-06 performance measures; PM-04 POA&M.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes systematic improvement identification. SP 800-53 generates findings but improvement process less formalized.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties
clauses.rationale: CA-08 penetration testing; IR-03 incident response testing; PM-14 testing/exercises; CP-04 contingency testing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 includes third-party coordination in testing. SP 800-53 covers testing but supplier coordination less explicit.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities
clauses.rationale: CA-07 continuous monitoring; PM-06 measures; IR-04 incident analysis; SI-04 system monitoring; AT-06 training feedback (new in Rev 5) provides operational feedback on training effectiveness.
clauses.gaps: Minor: AT-06 improves coverage by feeding operational training results back for improvement. CSF 2.0 emphasizes operational improvement identification.

clauses.title: Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved based on lessons learned and other factors
clauses.rationale: IR-08 incident response plan; IR-03 testing/lessons learned; CP-02 contingency plan; CP-04 contingency testing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization
clauses.rationale: IA family comprehensive for identity and credential management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions
clauses.rationale: IA-12 identity proofing; IA-04 identifier management; IA-05 authenticator management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated
clauses.rationale: IA-02 user authentication; IA-03 device authentication; IA-08 non-org users; IA-09 service identification.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified
clauses.rationale: IA-02 authentication; IA-05 authenticator management; SC-23 session authenticity; IA-08 non-org users.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 addresses identity federation and assertion protocols. SP 800-53 covers through authentication controls.

clauses.title: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
clauses.rationale: AC-02 account management; AC-03 access enforcement; AC-05 separation of duties; AC-06 least privilege; AC-24 access control decisions.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: PE-02 access authorizations; PE-03 access control; PE-06 monitoring; PE-08 access records.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
clauses.rationale: AT-02 awareness training; AT-03 role-based training; AT-06 training feedback (new in Rev 5) ensures training effectiveness is measured and reported; PM-13 workforce.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. AT-06 strengthens by providing feedback loop on training results.

clauses.title: Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
clauses.rationale: AT-03 role-based training; AT-06 training feedback (new in Rev 5) particularly important for specialized roles where failures indicate serious problems; PM-13 workforce development; IR-02 incident response training.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. AT-06 specifically notes that failures in critical roles may indicate serious problems.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-28 protection at rest; MP-04 media storage; MP-05 media transport; AC-03 access enforcement.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-08 transmission protection; SC-12 key management; SC-13 cryptographic protection; AC-17 remote access.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-04 information in shared resources; AC-03/AC-04 access and flow control; SC-39 process isolation.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 explicitly addresses data-in-use protection (confidential computing, memory protection). SP 800-53 covers through general controls but data-in-use is less explicitly addressed.

clauses.title: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested in accordance with policy
clauses.rationale: CP-09 system backup; CP-06 alternate storage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Configuration management practices are established and applied
clauses.rationale: CM family comprehensive for configuration management; PL-09 central management (new in Rev 5) enables centralized management of configuration controls.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. PL-09 strengthens by enabling centralized configuration management.

clauses.title: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: SI-02 flaw remediation; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-07 least functionality; CM-11 software installation.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: MA-02 controlled maintenance; MA-06 timely maintenance; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-08 inventory.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 addresses hardware lifecycle management holistically. SP 800-53 covers through maintenance and inventory controls.

clauses.title: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring
clauses.rationale: AU family comprehensive for log generation; CA-07 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Installation and execution of unauthorized software is prevented
clauses.rationale: CM-07 least functionality including application allowlisting (enhancements 4/5); CM-11 user-installed software; CM-14 signed components.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle
clauses.rationale: SA family comprehensive for secure development lifecycle.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage
clauses.rationale: SC-07 boundary protection; AC-04 information flow; AC-17 remote access; SC-32 partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats
clauses.rationale: PE family comprehensive for environmental protection.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
clauses.rationale: CP family contingency and resilience; SC-05 availability; SC-36 distributed processing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained
clauses.rationale: AU-04 audit storage capacity; CP-02 capacity planning; SC-05 denial of service; PE-11 emergency power capacity.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 addresses general capacity management. SP 800-53 covers specific capacity contexts but general IT capacity management less explicit.

clauses.title: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SI-04 system monitoring; SC-07 boundary monitoring; AU-06 audit review; CA-07 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: PE-06 monitoring physical access; PE-03 physical access control; PE-20 asset monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: AU-06 audit review; AU-12 audit generation; SI-04 system monitoring; AC-02 account management including automated auditing (enhancement 4).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SA-09 external service monitoring; SR-06 supplier assessments; CA-07 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses external service monitoring. SP 800-53 covers through general monitoring and service controls.

clauses.title: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SI-04 system monitoring; SI-07 software/firmware integrity; AU-06 audit review; CM-03 configuration change monitoring (enhancement 5).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities
clauses.rationale: SI-04 system monitoring; AU-06 audit analysis; IR-04 incident handling/analysis.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information is correlated from multiple sources
clauses.rationale: AU-06 audit analysis including integrated analysis (enhancement 5) and correlation (enhancement 3); SI-04 monitoring including correlation (enhancement 16); PL-09 central management (new in Rev 5) enables centralized correlation through enterprise security monitoring tools.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. PL-09 supports centralized correlation capabilities.

clauses.title: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident analysis includes impact assessment; RA-03 risk assessment provides impact framework; AU-06 audit analysis; SI-04 monitoring data for scope determination.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically requires impact and scope estimation during event analysis. SP 800-53 covers through incident analysis and risk assessment.

clauses.title: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools
clauses.rationale: SI-04 system alerts (enhancement 5); IR-06 incident reporting; AU-06 automated process integration (enhancement 1).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis
clauses.rationale: PM-16 threat awareness; RA-03 risk context; SI-05 advisories; RA-10 threat hunting.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes threat intelligence integration into analysis. SP 800-53 covers threat intelligence but analytical integration less explicit.

clauses.title: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes declaration; IR-05 incident monitoring; IR-06 reporting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling; IR-06 reporting; IR-07 assistance; IR-08 response plan.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incident reports are triaged and validated
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes triage; IR-05 incident monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incidents are categorized and prioritized
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes categorization; IR-05 monitoring for tracking.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes formal categorization and prioritization. SP 800-53 IR controls cover but with less categorization specificity.

clauses.title: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling; IR-06 reporting (includes escalation); IR-07 assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses escalation procedures. SP 800-53 covers through incident reporting.

clauses.title: The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes recovery initiation; CP-10 system recovery.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires specific recovery initiation criteria. SP 800-53 covers recovery but formal criteria less explicit.

clauses.title: Analysis is performed to determine what has taken place during an incident and root cause
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident analysis; AU-06 audit analysis; SI-04 monitoring data.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident documentation; AU-09 protection of audit information; AU-11 audit retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes investigation record integrity and chain of custody. SP 800-53 covers audit protection but forensic record provenance less explicit.

clauses.title: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident data collection; AU-03 audit content; AU-09 protection; AU-11 retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: Metadata and provenance focus is more specific in CSF 2.0 than in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident analysis; IR-05 monitoring; RA-03 impact assessment.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses magnitude estimation. SP 800-53 covers through incident analysis.

clauses.title: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-06 incident reporting; IR-07 incident response assistance and coordination.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders
clauses.rationale: IR-06 reporting; PM-15 security contacts; PM-16 threat awareness sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes structured incident information sharing. SP 800-53 covers reporting but information sharing mechanisms less detailed.

clauses.title: Incidents are contained
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes containment; SC-07 boundary protection for isolation.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incidents are eradicated
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling includes eradication; SI-03 malware removal.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process
clauses.rationale: CP-10 system recovery; IR-04 incident recovery; CP-02 contingency plan execution.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Recovery actions are selected, scoped, and prioritized, considering the business impact of the incident
clauses.rationale: CP-10 recovery; CP-02 prioritized contingency plan; IR-04 incident-informed recovery.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes business impact consideration in recovery prioritization. SP 800-53 covers through contingency planning.

clauses.title: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration
clauses.rationale: CP-09 system backup including testing for reliability/integrity (enhancement 1); SI-07 software and information integrity verification.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 explicitly requires integrity verification before restoration. CP-09 enhancement 1 covers backup testing.

clauses.title: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms
clauses.rationale: CP-10 recovery; IR-04 post-incident; PM-11 mission process definition.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 addresses establishment of new operational norms post-incident. SP 800-53 covers recovery but post-incident norm establishment less explicit.

clauses.title: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed
clauses.rationale: CP-10 system recovery; SI-07 integrity verification; CA-07 continuous monitoring for confirmation.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes post-recovery integrity verification. SP 800-53 covers through recovery and integrity controls.

clauses.title: The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling closure; IR-03 lessons learned documentation.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires formal recovery closure criteria. SP 800-53 covers incident closure but formal end-of-recovery criteria less explicit.

clauses.title: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders
clauses.rationale: IR-06 incident reporting (includes recovery status); IR-07 assistance; CP-02 communication plan.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes recovery-specific communication. SP 800-53 covers through incident reporting but recovery communication specifically is less detailed.

clauses.title: Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging
clauses.rationale: IR-06 reporting; IR-07 assistance for external communication.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses public communications. SP 800-53 covers incident reporting but public/media communications strategy less explicit.
